The image shows a histological section stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). The tissue appears to be brain tissue, characterized by large areas of pinkish-purple staining, which likely represents gliosis or reactive astrocytosis. There are also several small, irregularly shaped structures scattered throughout the tissue, which appear to be perivascular spaces or possibly small blood vessels. The overall appearance suggests a condition involving significant gliosis and possible demyelination.

Given these observations, the most likely diagnosis among the provided options is:

D. Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML)

This is because PML is known to cause extensive areas of demyelination and gliosis in the white matter of the brain, which is consistent with the large pinkish-purple areas seen in the image. The other options do not typically present with this specific histological pattern.
